response.answer_text: I know the popular answer is Wordpress or Blogger, but I think if you’re not going to spend the money to actually own your domain, it’s better to start on social media. If I was just getting started as a blogger and had zero dollars to invest, I’d use Medium. It’s free, which is what you’re looking for. It’s also super easy. You don’t have to do any design. Just open an account and write your first post. Voila! You can easy connect on Medium with friends you follow on Facebook and Twitter, which gives you a head start in the audience department. It’s relatively easy to publish with a Medium publication, which puts you in front of a wider audience. Medium is designed to be super shareable, so even without much of an audience of your own, if you write well and write consistently, you’ll have a chance of having a post gain some traction. I had a post get more than 80,000 views on Medium when I had fewer than 100 followers. You can add a free account at MailChimp to manage your email list and another one at Upscribe to make free forms to put in your Medium posts, to collect email addresses. I think it’s way more important to own your email list than it is to own your blog. Here’s the strategy I’d use (it’s the one I actually do use): Open an account at both Medium and Quora.Use Quora to explore blog topics. Check for questions in areas that interest you, that have some upvotes and followers. If people are paying attention and showing interest in a question, they’ll pay attention when you write about it in a blog post.So, write about it in a blog post on Medium.Check out some Medium publications and submit your posts to them. Be patient and don’t give up if your first attempts aren’t successful. If you keep writing, eventually Medium publications will come to you and ask if they can publish your work.Write on Medium at least once a week. Three times a week is better.Answer a question a day on Quora. Crosspost your best answers to Medium.Add an Upscribe form to the bottom of every Medium post. Remember: building an email list of readers is your goal.Link to your Medium profile in your Quora profile.Email your list twice a month: once to share cool stuff you didn’t write and once to share cool stuff you did. This is a good starter plan for how to use your email list. You might eventually get to where you’re emailing more often. A weekly newsletter with links to your Medium posts isn’t a bad idea.When you’re ready to put a little money into your blogging, go with a blog where you own the domain. (So: yourblog(dot)com instead of yourblog(dot)wordpress or blogger(dot)com.)By this time, you’ll have a better idea of who your audience is and what you want to write. Copy some of your best Medium posts to your new blog.Keep writing. Consistency is king.Good luck! Love,Shaunta P.S. Want to be a Ninja Writer? Start with this free 31 day challenge.

Hello, So you want to start a blog. That’s great! Not only is blogging a great pastime, but with a blog you can express yourself in a unique way, help others with problems you’ve overcome, establish yourself as an expert, and even make money. If you’re new to blogging, I will give to you a fast, foolproof guide to starting a blog, without having to learn HTML or waste your time reading long, boring tutorials. I’m going to walk you through the entire process of setting up your self-hosted blog, so you ‘get it right the first time. Step 1: Choose the right blogging platform (WordPress) Before you can even start worrying about how your blog will look like, you’ll need to choose your blogging platform.  There’s a lot to choose from. You are able to create a blog with many different blogging platforms, such as WordPress, Tumblr, Blogger and more… However, given that there are over 72 million active users using WordPress today, it’s clear which platform is the boss. So without a doubt, go with WordPress. Especially when you are just starting out. Why you shouldn’t create a blog on a free blogging platform Without a doubt, you need to self-host your WordPress blog. Think about it – what famous, successful blogger you know is using a free blogging website instead of their own domain name? Web hosting – This will be the home of your blog address and content that’s on the blog. Without web hosting, you’ll be unable to use your domain. Think of it as a computer hard drive that stores all your content on your blog (images, blog posts and so on). The cost of web hosting is usually somewhere between $2-5 per month. It’s less than an XL coffee at Starbucks, so it won’t break the bank. But it’s an important investment to your blog success. Where should I get my domain name and hosting? There are lots of platforms you can use for free to start your blog, from WordPress and Blogger to Medium and LinkedIn. The first question you have to ask though is this: Why are you starting a blog? If it’s for fun, I recommend Medium as it’s easy to use and requires zero setup on your part. Just create an account and publish whenever you wish. If it’s for business, then you need to re-think how you’re about to proceed. Are you blogging to establish your authority? Are you hoping to promote your business? Or are you planning to monetize your blog content? If any or all of those things are true, you cannot proceed with a free blog. First, you do not own a free blog - it’s a free subscription somewhere that can be taken away from you at any time for any reason. If you’re just blogging for fun, there’s not much risk there. But if you’re working hard at creating content to build a business and suddenly it’s all gone, that should be a terrifying and paralyzing thought. Note: this is not dramatic hype designed to irrationally frighten you. Posterous, a free blogging site like Tumblr that was bought by Twitter and was the home of 4 million bloggers was ultimately shut down. At least those users had some notice and time to grab their content! Others whose accounts have been incorrectly flagged and suspended on various platforms aren’t as lucky.
